text: Yes, well, audiences are idiots. I also think US is better than GET OUT!
author: SonnyBunch

text: The huge opening of this film that is not based on a previous property and has no real stars suggests that Jordan Peele, Director was the draw here. And that’s good news! But ... audiences have a tendency to tire of horror auteurs.
author: SonnyBunch

text: GET OUT ended up grossing about 5.5 times its opening weekend, domestically. I wouldn’t be surprised if US does 2.5x. Which would still put it in the $160M range! Not bad for a flick that cost $20M.
author: SonnyBunch

text: By way of comparison, GET OUT had an A-minus. US getting a B suggests that audiences are slightly less forgiving than critics of the fact that US *doesn’t make any sense at all.*
author: SonnyBunch

text: So, US looks set for a huge weekend. Mid-to-high sixties. That’s great news: Peele more than tripled the production budget and it should recoup all costs by the end of next weekend. But! That B CinemaScore. https://deadline.com/2019/03/us-jordan-peele-weekend-box-office-1202580617/ …

text: Speaking of framing: I thing I would read is a visual essay explaining how it is that he manages every shot to look like a work of art on its own. I don’t have the language for it, but it’s amazing.
author: SonnyBunch

text: The one-act play, as you describe it in your piece, strikes me as the ideal version of this. There’s no reason for it, really, except to create a moral and philosophical universe concordant with the rest of his work. And it’s perfectly shot, perfectly framed, perfectly cut.
author: SonnyBunch

text: This is not to say that Zahler is Anonioni-esque, or anything like that. There’s just a similarly deliberate pace, a similar mood of timing. I don’t know how to describe it, exactly.
author: SonnyBunch

text: There’s something about watching Zahler’s films that reminds me of watching THE PASSENGER or L’AVVENTURA in college: this comfort with taking your time, letting people make themselves known, absorbing the setting.
author: SonnyBunch

text: I really enjoyed this profile of S. Craig Zahler by @scott_tobias. This bit jumps out: https://www.theringer.com/movies/2019/3/22/18276913/s-craig-zahler-dragged-across-concrete-brawl-in-cell-block-99 …

Two things worth noting: Tim Heidecker is the low-key MVP of US. And Tory Kittles is the low-key MVP of DRAGGED ACROSS CONCRETE. 

Given the Oscar-caliber talent in both films, this really surprised me.

text: I honestly don’t play enough games to be a useful game critic. One must know one’s limitations!
author: SonnyBunch

text: This video remains the most important meta text on video game criticism I have ever seen. Intellectual wanking vs. superficial descriptions of how fun the game is seem to be kind of the only options?
author: SonnyBunch

text: But also because most video game writing is only *useful* if it tells fans of the genre being reviewed if the game is FUN TO PLAY within the context of the genre.
author: SonnyBunch

text: I had kicked around the idea of writing a big piece on the state of video game criticism as compared to early film criticism a few (maybe five) years back and never quite got it to gel. Partly because with a very few exceptions most video game writing is terrible.

text:
A 55% second weekend drop is about average. Suggests a weaker hold than WONDER WOMAN or BLACK PANTHER but is roughly the median for MCU movies. 

$760M worldwide after 10 days is very good, obviously. Split’s about 2:1 domestic to worldwide, which suggests $1B total likely.

author: SonnyBunch

text:
“Can I interview you for a book I’m writing?”
“I’d rather not, I don’t need headaches on the campaign trail.”
“It’s on an unrelated topic, I’m not even covering the race.”
“OK, fine, but you can’t use anything I say until after Election Day.”
“Deal.” 

This is … not scandalous.
author: SonnyBunch

text: Completely different situation and also that story sounded like bullshit from the beginning anyway.
author: SonnyBunch

text:
“I want to interview you for my book.”
“I’d rather not.”
“C’mon, it’s for a book, I’m not covering the Senate race."
“Fine, but you can’t use anything I tell you in the interview before Election Day.”
“Yeah, OK.” 

There’s nothing particularly damning about this.
